questions.question_text: An organization is evaluating options related to moving organizational assets to a cloud-based environment using an IaaS provider. One engineer has suggested connecting a second cloud environment within the organization's existing facilities to capitalize on available datacenter space and resources. Other project team members are concerned about such a commitment of organizational assets, and ask the Chief Security Officer (CSO) for input. The CSO explains that the project team should work with the engineer to evaluate the risks associated with using the datacenter to implement:

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
One engineer suggests a cloud environment within the organization's existing facilities to use existing datacenter space (suggesting private). Other team members don't want to commit to just using organizational assets (suggesting public). A hybrid cloud combines public/private cloud, so A seems like the answer.

"Hybrid cloud refers to a mixed computing, storage, and services environment made up of on-premises infrastructure, private cloud services, and a public cloud—such as Amazon Web Services (AWS) or Microsoft Azure—with orchestration among the various platforms."

https://www.netapp.com/hybrid-cloud/what-is-hybrid-cloud/#:~:text=Hybrid%20cloud%20refers%20to%20a,orchestration%20among%20the%20various%20platforms.

comments.content:
I think option C says "hosted" to throw us off since public clouds are "by definition hosted by a public cloud provider such as AWS, Azure, or Google Cloud... [since they] alleviate the responsibility for management of the infrastructure." But private clouds are not necessarily "hosted" because they "utilize an organization’s own infrastructure." Hence, a hybrid cloud cannot be "hosted" because it includes private cloud services.

https://www.vmware.com/topics/glossary/content/private-cloud-vs-public-cloud.html

discussion.content: The question seems incomplete but there are two different things here. 1. They are moving to to cloud 2. They are renting out the existing data-center resources to a cloud provider.

Hybrid cloud hosting is a model that allows organizations to provision dedicated servers and storage and shared cloud servers and storage on the same network. A hybrid cloud consists of a minimum of one private cloud (also known as an internal cloud) and one public cloud (or external cloud). https://searchstorage.techtarget.com/definition/hybrid-cloud-hosting

A
There is no such thing as a "hosted hybrid cloud." A hybrid cloud is a mix of on-prem and private cloud. Multi-cloud is using 2 or more private cloud providers. Either way, the question is describing using a cloud provider and joining it to an on-prem datacenter. That is the definition of a hybrid cloud environment.

comments.content:
From the question: "One engineer has suggested connecting a second cloud environment within the organizations existing facilities."
Note: "a second cloud environment"
Arguably, this is not one cloud that is a mix of on-premise and off-premise; but is two clouds, one on-premise and one-off premise

Then again, according to Redhat: "Hybrid cloud is an IT architecture that incorporates some degree of workload portability, orchestration, and management across 2 or more environments. "
https://www.redhat.com/en/topics/cloud-computing/what-is-hybrid-cloud

I don't think I have seen anything about "hosted" cloud services. I thought, unless using a private cloud, it's all hosted by the cloud service provider?

https://www.netcov.com/difference-between-cloud-and-hosted-services/
I think this should be A. It would be an on premises private cloud since the org would be the one hosting it.

discussion.content:
Maybe: D. a private cloud?
A "cloud environment within the organization's existing facilities" would mean the cloud is private. Nothing hybrid about that.

questions.question_text:
A Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) is reviewing the results of a gap analysis with an outside cybersecurity consultant. The gap analysis reviewed all procedural and technical controls and found the following:
✑ High-impact controls implemented: 6 out of 10
✑ Medium-impact controls implemented: 409 out of 472
✑ Low-impact controls implemented: 97 out of 1000
The report includes a cost-benefit analysis for each control gap. The analysis yielded the following information:
✑ Average high-impact control implementation cost: $15,000; Probable ALE for each high-impact control gap: $95,000
✑ Average medium-impact control implementation cost: $6,250; Probable ALE for each medium-impact control gap: $11,000
Due to the technical construction and configuration of the corporate enterprise, slightly more than 50% of the medium-impact controls will take two years to fully implement. Which of the following conclusions could the CISO draw from the analysis?

discussion.content: I don't see any reason why C wouldn't be correct. Definitely a strange question either way.

choices.C: Because of the significant ALE for each high-risk vulnerability, efforts should be focused on those controls
choices.A: Too much emphasis has been placed on eliminating low-risk vulnerabilities in the past
choices.B: The enterprise security team has focused exclusively on mitigating high-level risks
choices.D: The cybersecurity team has balanced residual risk for both high and medium controls

questions.question_text:
During a recent incident, sensitive data was disclosed and subsequently destroyed through a properly secured, cloud-based storage platform. An incident response technician is working with management to develop an after action report that conveys critical metrics regarding the incident.
Which of the following would be MOST important to senior leadership to determine the impact of the breach?

choices.C: The amount of downtime required to restore the data
choices.A: The likely per-record cost of the breach to the organization
choices.B: The legal or regulatory exposure that exists due to the breach

comments.content: Curios, how do you know you got that particular question correct?

discussion.content: I had a similar question on a CISSP exam and the answer was D. The number of records compromised is the top level and needs to be determined before you can answer the other choices.
Possible worth noting: the question specifically states the platform was "properly secured." As such, shouldn't "legal or regulatory exposure" be minimal?
IMO: this should be a two answer question, and those answers should be A & D. Senior leadership wants to know the bottom line.

questions.question_text:
After an employee was terminated, the company discovered the employee still had access to emails and attached content that should have been destroyed during the off-boarding. The employee's laptop and cell phone were confiscated and accounts were disabled promptly. Forensic investigation suggests the company's
DLP was effective, and the content in question was not sent outside of work or transferred to removable media. Personality owned devices are not permitted to access company systems or information.
Which of the following would be the MOST efficient control to prevent this from occurring in the future?

discussion.content:
Maybe: D. Prevent backup of mobile devices to personally owned computers?
Maybe the employee took his company phone home, and did a backup of the emails into his personal laptop? The question states: " Personality owned devices are not permitted to access company systems or information." But he didn't access the phone with his laptop, he accessed his laptop with the company phone. If he takes his phone home, and everybody does, it would not help to "Restrict access to company systems to expected times of day and geographic locations."

Selected Answer: D
D. Prevent backup of mobile devices to personally owned computers.

comments.content: At first I thought C because "still had access to emails and attached content" made me think this employee still had access to the organization's email services, but I think it's just saying they had access to emails that had been previously exchanged before leaving the organization (like historical email and their attachments). If that understanding is correct then the answer is D because they backed up all their emails onto their personal device.

choices.D: Prevent backup of mobile devices to personally owned computers.
choices.E: Perform unannounced insider threat testing on high-risk employees.
choices.A: Install application whitelist on mobile devices.
choices.C: Restrict access to company systems to expected times of day and geographic locations.
choices.B: Disallow side loading of applications on mobile devices.

questions.question_text: A systems analyst is concerned that the current authentication system may not provide the appropriate level of security. The company has integrated WAYF within its federation system and implemented a mandatory two-step authentication system. Some accounts are still becoming compromised via phishing attacks that redirect users to a fake portal, which is automatically collecting and replaying the stolen credentials. Which of the following is a technical solution that would BEST reduce the risk of similar compromises?

discussion.content: I believe tokens and OTPs can be replayed in an attack. I lean toward B (push based) because an attacker would need your device vs being able to intercept a token/OTP and replay it.

comments.content: You wish you knew how wrong that is. OAuth tokens are only granted to those who have authorization code, like a website that's trying to use your credentials on a different website, and then ON THE BACKEND they request OAuth token by supplying authorization code in order to access resource server. Please be careful what you post, you're misleading people as someone liked your post. "D" - you should've began answering this question by eliminating D immediately.

discussion.content: The question mentions that the company has a federation system. I took this as a clue and picked D as my answer.

According to the question, the company has already "implemented a mandatory two-step authentication system"
Does that mean the company is already implementing 2FA?
If so, would TOTP be all that useful?

comments.content:
You're right, TOTP "is a common form of two factor authentication (2FA)." I couldn't find anything on specifically software-based TOTP. I don't think it's a thing.

https://www.twilio.com/docs/glossary/totp

discussion.content: I think user awareness training should be the answer here.

comments.content: Specifically asks for a technical control. That's not a technical control.
I was thinking the answer is security awareness training because they are phishing attacks.
But Trap_D0_r is correct, security awareness training is not a technical control.
